Coffee production begins when the seeds from coffee
cherries (the Coffea  plant's fruits) are separated to
produce unroasted green coffee beans . The "beans" are
roasted  and then ground into fine particles. Coffee is
brewed from the ground roasted beans, which are
typically steeped in hot water before being filtered out.</s>

[Language: english] e fermentation is finished, the seeds are washed with large quantities of fresh water to remove the
fermentation residue, which generates massive amounts of coffee wastewater . Finally , the seeds are

The best (but least used) method of drying coffee is using drying tables. In this method, the pulped and
fermented coffee is spread thinly on raised beds, which allows the air to pass on all sides of the coffee,
and then the coffee is mixed by hand.

[Language: english] beds, which allows the air to pass on all sides of the coffee,
and then the coffee is mixed by hand. The drying that then takes place is more uniform, and fermentation
is less likely . Most African coffee is dried in this manner and certain coffee farms around the world are
starting to use this traditional method.[106] Next, the coffee is sorted, and labeled as green coffee. Some
companies use cylinders to pump in heated air to dry the coffee seeds, though this is generally in places</s>

[Language: english] g at the

Drip brewers  and automatic coffeemakers  brew coffee using
gravity . In an automatic coffeemaker , hot water drips onto
coffee grounds that are held in a paper , plastic, or perforated
metal coffee filter , allowing the water to seep through the
ground coffee while extracting its oils and essences. The
liquid drips through the coffee and the filter into a carafe or
pot, and the spent coffee grounds  are retained in the filter .[130]

[Language: english] nd the filter into a carafe or
pot, and the spent coffee grounds  are retained in the filter .[130]
In a coffee percolator , water is pulled under a pipe by gravity ,
which is then forced into a chamber above a filter by steam
pressure created by boiling. The water then seeps through the
grounds, and the process is repeated until terminated by removing it from the heat, by an internal
timer ,[131] or by a thermostat that turns of f the heater when the entire pot reaches a certain temperature.</s>

Some coffee is sold through internet auction – much of it is sold through a competition, with coffees

[Language: english] me coffee is sold through internet auction – much of it is sold through a competition, with coffees
passing through local and international jurors, and then the best coffees being selected to be bid on. Some
estates known for high-quality coffee also sell their coffee through an online auction. This can lead to
increased price transparency since the final price paid is usually published.[172]

La plupart de ces composés se dégradent à l’air et à la lumière , ce qui explique le conseil usuel de conserver le café
moulu dans un récipient hermétique sous vide, à l’abri de la chaleur et de la lumière. Conserver le café sous forme de
grains et le moudre au dernier moment minimise la surface de contact avec l’air, et donc la probabilité de dégradation
des arômes.</s>

Coffee is best stored in an airtight conta iner made of ceramic, glass or
non-reactive metal.[121] Higher quality prepackaged coffee usually has
a one-way valve that prevents air from entering while allowing the
coffee to release gases.[122] Coffee freshness and flavor is preserved
when it is stored away from moisture, heat, and light. The tendency of

[Language: english] ness and flavor is preserved
when it is stored away from moisture, heat, and light. The tendency of
coffee to absorb strong smells from food means that it should be kept
away from such smells. Storage of coffee in refrigerators is not
recommended due to the presence of moisture which can cause
deterioration. Exterior walls of buildings that face the sun may heat the
interior of a home, and this heat may damage coffee stored near such a
wall. Heat from nearby ovens also harms stored cof fee.</s>

An Asian coffee known as kopi luwak  under goes a peculiar
process made from coffee berries eaten by the Asian palm
civet , passing through its digestive tract, with the beans
eventually harvested from feces . Coffee brewed from this
process[107] is among the most expensive in the world, with
bean prices reaching $160 per pound or $30 per brewed
cup.</s>

[Language: english] rent varieties of seeds differ in moisture and density and therefore roast at different rates.[112]
During roasting, caramelization  occurs as intense heat breaks down starches , changing them to simple
sugars that begin to brown, which darkens the color of the bean.[113]
Sucrose is rapidly lost during the roasting process, and may disappear entirely  in darker roasts. During
roasting, aromatic oils and acids weaken, changing the flavor; at 205 °C (401 °F), other oils start to
develop.

The espresso  method forces hot pressurized water through finely-ground coffee.[129] As a result of
brewing under high pressure (typically 9 bar),[132] the espresso beverage is more concentrated (as much
as 10 to 15 times the quantity of coffee to water as gravity-brewing methods can produce) and has a more
complex physical and chemical constitution.</s>

Drip brewers  and automatic coffeemakers  brew coffee using
gravity . In an automatic coffeemaker , hot water drips onto
coffee grounds that are held in a paper , plastic, or perforated
metal coffee filter , allowing the water to seep through the
ground coffee while extracting its oils and essences. The
liquid drips through the coffee and the filter into a carafe or
pot, and the spent coffee grounds  are retained in the filter .[130]</s>
